title: Introductory Calculus Lecture 1
summary: This lecture introduces the syllabus for Introductory Calculus, covering differential equations, line and double integrals, and calculus of functions in two variables. It also reviews practical information like lecture times, problem sheets, and recommended reading. The lecture includes examples of differential equations from physics and engineering, as well as a review of integration techniques such as integration by parts and separable equations.

concepts.name: Differential Equations
concepts.description: Equations involving an independent variable, a function of that variable, and the derivatives of that function. They can be ordinary (ODEs) or partial (PDEs).

concepts.name: Integration Techniques
concepts.description: Methods for finding the integral of a function, including integration by parts, substitution, and using reduction formulas.

concepts.name: Separable Equations
concepts.description: A type of differential equation that can be solved by separating the variables and integrating each side independently.

concepts.name: Integration by Parts
concepts.description: A technique used to integrate the product of two functions, based on the product rule of differentiation.

notes.heading: Syllabus
bullets: First half (7-8 lectures): Differential Equations (ODEs and PDEs).
Second part: Line and double integrals (3 lectures).
Final part: Calculus of functions in two variables (gentle introduction to multivariable calculus).
Topics include: surfaces, gradient normal vectors, Taylor's theorem, critical points, Lagrange multipliers.
Course interacts with Multivariable Calculus, Dynamics, PDEs (Fourier Series), and Analysis 2.
Useful and mandatory course.

notes.heading: Examples of Differential Equations
bullets: ODE: Equation involving an independent variable (x), a function of x (y), and derivatives of y with respect to x.
Order of ODE: The order of the highest derivative.
Simplest ODE: dy/dx = f(x). Solved by direct integration.
Mechanics: Newton's second law (F=ma). Acceleration is a derivative (a = dv/dt = d^2r/dt^2).
Electrical Circuit (RLC): Resistor (R), Inductor (L), Capacitor (C), Voltage Source (V).
Kirchhoff's Law: V(t) = RI + Q/C + L(dI/dt).
Differential equation for RLC circuit: L(d^2Q/dt^2) + R(dQ/dt) + (1/C)Q = V.
Radioactive Decay: Rate of decay is proportional to the remaining number of atoms (exercise).

notes.heading: Review of Integration
bullets: Integration by Parts: Based on the product rule: (fg)' = f'g + fg'.
Integration by parts formula: ∫fg' dx = fg - ∫f'g dx.
Example: ∫x^2 sin(x) dx. Choose f = x^2, g' = sin(x). Result: -x^2 cos(x) + 2 ∫x cos(x) dx.
Example: ∫(2x-1) ln(x^2+1) dx. Choose f = ln(x^2+1), g' = 2x-1.
Example: Reduction formula for  I_n = ∫cos^n(x) dx. Result: I_n = (1/n)cos^(n-1)(x)sin(x) + ((n-1)/n)I_(n-2).
Separable Equations: dy/dx = a(x)b(y).
Separate and integrate: ∫(1/b(y)) dy = ∫a(x) dx.
Example: x(y^2-1) + y(x^2-1)(dy/dx) = 0. General solution: (1-y^2)(1-x^2) = C, where C >= 0.

A differential equation involving partial derivatives of a function of several variables.
The order of the highest derivative that occurs in the differential equation.
A technique for integrating the product of two functions using the formula ∫ u dv = uv - ∫ v du.
A differential equation that can be written in the form dy/dx = a(x)b(y), allowing separation of variables for integration.

examples.description: Newton's Second Law (F=ma) as a Differential Equation
examples.relevance: Illustrates how differential equations arise in mechanics, with acceleration being the second derivative of displacement with respect to time.
Demonstrates how differential equations model electrical circuits, relating voltage, current, charge, resistance, inductance, and capacitance.
Example that the rate at which a radioactive substance decays is proportional to the remaining number of atoms; provides an exercise for the student.
